Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, probably an olpe; interior reserved; exterior: double dot frieze at top; at left, part of black handle zone; in panel, black-figure decoration consisting of warrior and elderly male figure to right (of warrior, helmeted head decorated with added white dots and part of round shield with added red trim and unusual blazon in white remain; of elderly male figure, head, white hair and beard, and part of tunic decorated with white dots).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 129, pl. XXXIX, no. 358.2)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 235, no. 212)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1991)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5738 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
